response: And if to achieve that right, is neccesary for us to renegate of the most rooted feelings of caste and family so it be.

context/1: Congressman Esquivel has pretended, denouncing an alleged affair, comitted by my father disimulate the gravity of the present situation, in which freedoom of speech which is the root of people´s liberty, can be severely damaged.
context/2: The written word is stoic, in action...
context/3: His moral solvency and his word made truth.
context/4: Man has, in his defense, against possible agressions of the intelligence only one thing!
context/5: A gear without hierarchy in the monstrous social machinery.
context/6: The man in his most pure manifestation which leads him to express his feelings his truth, despite growing danger... because, precisely, the truth of every man can become a danger for those that want that the individual to be a spring.
context/7: Personal issues are solved in another field.
context/8: But this is not about making personal defenses.
context/9: pretended to diminish, not only my position, but of our Party.

response: Lieutenant, your testimony will be required at the trial of Colonel Chivington in the matter of the Sand Creek massacre.
context/0: The evidence is overwhelming, and I might add some of it downright attractive.
context/1: Also the numerous reports I've received prove that the wrong man has been on trial here.
context/2: Just long enough to admit that the South has counter-attacked in force and... we've lost this engagement.
context/3: That depends.
context/5: Sergeant Lebbard, have the bugler sound assembly.
context/6: The good Lord let me know if something worth fighting for, a body better fight.
context/8: Mr. Colonel... if there's any driving to do, we'll do it.
context/9: You women clear out of here before I have you driven out.

context: You're supposed to be doing a skirmish, not dancing a polka.
context/3: Tuck them in!
context/8: Most any three men.
context/9: Better than any three men, Lieutenant, any three men.

context/3: They're all right.
context/5: I think I'd better call them.
context/8: Charlie, you hear that?
context/9: You have just listening to General Montgomery Smith.

response: What are you sitting there for, letting me take the blame?
context/2: You mean, you deliberately aimed at Mrs. Granger and Lutts got in the way?
context/3: She was supposed to be the one.
context/8: No, no.
context/9: then you murdered George Lutts.

context/1: Tell me, Sergeant, in your professional opinion, do you really believe you can catch this man if he doesn't want you to?
context/3: You seem to have made a great study of crime, Mr. Newspaperman.
context/4: The ones we don't know about yet.
context/6: Now, you say the murderer is always caught because all the ones we know of have been caught.
context/7: Now, there must be many others who have never been discovered.
context/8: Well, those people killed and were discovered only years afterwards by accident or belated confession.
context/9: Aye, I have.
